Situation1: The meeting will cover key project updates that won’t be summarized elsewhere.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Polls stay open all day and the voter has a light schedule.
Story: I glanced at the clock on my computer screen, feeling the pressure mount. Our team meeting was scheduled to start in fifteen minutes, and I knew this one was crucial—our manager had made it clear that today’s updates wouldn’t be shared in an email or recorded. As a colleague, I was expected to be present, to contribute, and to show my commitment to the project. But as I checked my phone, a reminder popped up: today was election day. The polling station was open all day, and my workload was light, so there was no real excuse to put it off. I’d promised myself I’d vote, and I knew how important it was to participate. Yet, the meeting overlapped with the time I’d planned to go, and I felt torn. If I skipped the meeting, I’d let my team down and miss out on vital information. If I delayed voting, I worried something might come up later, and I’d lose my chance. My stomach twisted as I weighed the expectations—responsible colleague or responsible citizen? I stared at my calendar, paralyzed, unable to choose.
